metadata.case_name: Seth Fateh Chand v. Lala Balkishan Das

facts.text: By registered deed of lease dated May 19, 1927, renewed on January 30, 1947, Delhi Improvement Trust granted 90-year leasehold rights to Dr. M. Joshi for plot No. 3, E Block, Qarol Bagh, Delhi, admeasuring 2433 sq. yards.
Dr. Joshi constructed a building on the land.
Chandrawati, widow of Dr. Joshi and guardian of minor son Murli Manohar, sold leasehold rights and building to plaintiff Lala Balkishan Das by sale-deed dated April 21, 1947 for Rs. 63,000.
Plaintiff agreed to sell rights in land and building to defendant Seth Fateh Chand by agreement dated March 21, 1949 for Rs. 1,12,500; Rs. 1,000 paid as earnest money.

Agreement conditions: Plaintiff to deliver vacant possession by March 30, 1949; defendant to pay Rs. 24,000 then; sale deed registered by June 1, 1949. If defendant fails, Rs. 25,000 forfeited, possession returned. If plaintiff delays, pays Rs. 25,000 damages.
Southern boundary described as 'Bungalow of Murli Manohar Joshi'.
On March 25, 1949, plaintiff received Rs. 24,000 and delivered possession of building and land to defendant.
Sale not completed by June 1, 1949; each party blamed the other.

Plaintiff sued in Subordinate Judge, Delhi, for possession, Rs. 6,500 mesne profits from March 25, 1949 to Jan 24, 1950, and inquiry for future mesne profits; claimed agreement rescinded, Rs. 25,000 forfeited.
Defendant resisted, claimed plaintiff breached, no forfeiture.

Trial judge held plaintiff failed to put defendant in full possession, could not retain Rs. 25,000; directed plaintiff deposit Rs. 25,000 less Rs. 1,400 mesne profits prior to suit, defendant give possession; future mesne at Rs. 140/pm up to 3 years.
Punjab High Court (Circuit Bench Delhi) in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 37-D of 1960 modified: plaintiff retain Rs. 11,250 of Rs. 25,000 as compensation; mesne at Rs. 265/pm.
Defendant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).
Plaintiff's case: Sold leasehold from Joshi sale-deed April 21, 1947; defendant inspected deed, lease, plan; handed copy of plan; put in possession; defendant failed to pay balance, get deed.

Defendant's case: Plaintiff to sell per Improvement Trust plan boundaries; promised demarcate southern boundary, build wall; no sale deed/lease/plan shown at agreement; plan copy given later; shortage on south; plaintiff neglected to deliver full land/wall.
Commissioner measured land delivered: 141/142 ft by 157/158 ft; irregularities due to latrine/garage on adjacent Joshi property.
Defendant's letter June 17, 1949 first mentioned Joshi encroachment.
Land possessed by defendant exceeded 2433 sq. yards, within agreement boundaries.
Prior tenant rent: aggregate Rs. 150/pm for two houses; post-sale, Rs. 80/pm for this house to plaintiff.

legal_issues.text: Who committed breach of the contract?
Plaintiff's right to forfeit Rs. 25,000 (Rs. 1,000 earnest + Rs. 24,000 part price), and quantum of reasonable compensation under S.74 Contract Act.
Amount of mesne profits payable by defendant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff committed breach by not delivering full land per Improvement Trust plan, not demarcating southern boundary, not building wall; shortage/encroachment by Joshi.
Rs. 24,000 not earnest; forfeiture clause penalty, only reasonable compensation allowable.
Mesne profits limited to standard rent under Delhi Rent Control Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Ajmer-Merwara Rent Control Act XIX of 1947

respondent_arguments.text: Agreed to sell 2433 sq. yards per sale deed from Joshi; defendant inspected documents; delivered possession of agreed land; defendant failed to pay balance, complete sale.
Entire Rs. 25,000 earnest money, forfeitable on defendant's default.

court_reasoning.text: Defendant committed breach: no evidence oral terms for plan/wall in agreement; defendant paid Rs.24k on possession without protest; story of plan not seen unbelievable; land exceeded 2433 sq yds within boundaries; first encroachment plea June 17, 1949.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendant failed to pay balance, show willingness for conveyance.

court_reasoning.text: Rs.1,000 earnest forfeitable; Rs.24,000 part price, not earnest/security. Forfeiture clause penalty under S.74 Contract Act; applies to forfeiture of paid amounts; only reasonable compensation, no proof of loss beyond earnest + use of Rs.24k + separate mesne profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.74 eliminates English distinctions, covers all penalties including forfeiture; High Court cases like Abdul Gani, Natesa Aiyar wrongly limit to future payments.

court_reasoning.text: Mesne profits: Rs.140/pm by trial court reasonable (near prior rents); not 5% on arbitrary value; include 6% interest per CPC s.2(12); from June 1, 1949 to possession (max 3 yrs).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mesne profits = value of user, not return on capital value.

holdings.text: Under S.74 Contract Act, plaintiff entitled to forfeit only Rs.1,000 earnest as reasonable compensation; return balance of Rs.24,000.
Mesne profits at Rs.140 per mensem from June 1, 1949 till delivery of possession (max 3 years from decree) + 6% interest month to month.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Gani Co. v. Trustees of the Port of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Held S.74 applies only to sums to be paid in future, not forfeiture of paid amounts; court disagrees.
Held S.74 not for forfeiture of already paid sums; court holds it applies to all penalty stipulations including forfeiture.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs compensation for breach where sum named or penalty stipulated; reasonable compensation not exceeding named amount, applies to forfeiture clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Mesne profits inquiry; definition includes interest; limit to 3 years.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Ajmer-Merwara Rent Control Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned for standard rent limit on mesne profits, but no evidence of standard rent provided.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held defendant breached contract; plaintiff to retain only Rs.1,000 earnest from Rs.25,000; mesne profits at Rs.140/pm + 6% interest from June 1, 1949 to possession delivery (max 3 years); set aside High Court's Rs.11,250 damages and Rs.265/pm; parties bear own costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Plaintiff: retain Rs.1,000; mesne profits Rs.140/pm + interest; possession (implicit). Defendant: refund Rs.24,000.
outcome.costs: Parties bear their own costs in this Court.

key_quotes.text: "The section is clearly an attempt to eliminate the somewhat elaborate refinements made under the English common law in distinguishing between stipulations providing for payment of liquidated damages and stipulations in the nature of penalty."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legislative intent of S.74 Contract Act.

key_quotes.text: "In our judgment the expression 'the contract contains any other stipulation by way of penalty' comprehensively applies to every covenant involving a penalty whether it is for payment on breach of contract of money or delivery of property in future, or for forfeiture of right to money or other property already delivered."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding extending S.74 to forfeiture clauses.

key_quotes.text: "Mesne profits as defined in s. 2(12) of the Code of Civil Procedure are profits which the person in wrongful possession of property actually received or might with ordinary diligence have received therefrom, together with interest on such profits."
key_quotes.speaker: court
